Metadata.Title: Do Not Trust HTTP Header Information
Metadata.DirectLink: Do Not Trust HTTP Header Information
Metadata.Priority: J.D. Meier, Alex Mackman, Michael Dunner, Srinath Vasireddy, Ray Escamilla and Anandha Murukan

Content.Data:
Applies to

  • Web Application

What to Do

Do not make security decisions based on information in HTTP headers.

Why

An attacker can easily manipulate the information in HTTP headers. The value of the HTTP referrer filed can be easily changed by the client creating vulnerablities.

When

When making any security decisions, don't rely on the Header information.

How

HTTP headers are sent at the start of HTTP requests and HTTP responses. Your Web application should make sure it does not base any security decision on information in the HTTP headers because it is easy for an attacker to manipulate the header. For example, the referer field in the header contains the URL of the Web page from where the request originated. Do not make any security decisions based on the value of the referer field, for example, to check whether the request originated from a page generated by the Web application, because the field is easily falsified. 

Additional Resources

  • For more information see, "Chapter 4 - Design Guidelines for Secure Web Applications" at http://msdn2.microsoft.com/en-us/library/aa302420.aspx
